Overview: A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood glucose resulting from impaired insulin production and/or action; includes type 1, type 2, and gestational diabetes.
Symptoms: Frequent urination, Increased thirst, Unexplained weight loss or gain, Fatigue, Blurred vision
Causes: Type 1: autoimmune beta-cell destruction; Type 2: insulin resistance + beta-cell dysfunction; genetic factors, obesity, sedentary lifestyle
Treatments: Lifestyle modification (diet, exercise, weight loss), blood glucose monitoring, diabetes education, insulin therapy when required, manage complications
Medications: Metformin, Insulin, Sulfonylureas (e.g., glibenclamide), SGLT2 inhibitors, DPP-4 inhibitors

Overview: A chronic condition with persistently elevated arterial blood pressure that increases risk of heart disease, stroke, and kidney disease.
Symptoms: Often asymptomatic; may cause headaches, dizziness, nosebleeds, shortness of breath in severe cases
Causes: Age, high salt intake, obesity, sedentary lifestyle, genetics, excessive alcohol, some medications
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (salt reduction, weight loss, exercise), regular BP monitoring, treat secondary causes, pharmacologic therapy when indicated
Medications: ACE inhibitors (e.g., lisinopril), ARBs, Calcium channel blockers, Beta blockers, Diuretics

Overview: A chronic inflammatory disease of the airways causing episodic wheeze, breathlessness, chest tightness and cough, often triggered by allergens or irritants.
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, Wheeze, Chest tightness, Cough (worse at night/early morning)
Causes: Allergic sensitization, viral respiratory infections, air pollution, exercise, occupational exposures, genetic predisposition
Treatments: Identify and avoid triggers, inhaled short-acting bronchodilators for relief, inhaled corticosteroids for control, asthma action plan, immunotherapy for allergic asthma
Medications: Short-acting beta-agonists (albuterol/salbutamol), Inhaled corticosteroids (fluticasone), Long-acting bronchodilators for control (LABA) combined with steroids

Overview: A parasitic infection caused by Plasmodium species transmitted via Anopheles mosquitoes; ranges from mild febrile illness to severe life-threatening disease.
Symptoms: Fever (often cyclical), Chills, Sweating, Headache, Muscle aches, Fatigue, Nausea
Causes: Infection with Plasmodium falciparum, vivax, ovale, malariae via mosquito bite; travel to endemic areas
Treatments: Prompt parasitological diagnosis (RDT or microscopy), antimalarial therapy appropriate to species and resistance patterns, supportive care (fluids, antipyretics), prevention (bed nets, chemoprophylaxis)
Medications: Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs), Chloroquine (where sensitive), Primaquine for hypnozoites (P. vivax/ovale) under guidance

Overview: A recurrent headache disorder with moderate-to-severe head pain often accompanied by nausea and sensitivity to light/noise; may have aura.
Symptoms: Throbbing/one-sided headache, Nausea/vomiting, Photophobia, Phonophobia, Aura (visual or sensory) in some
Causes: Genetic predisposition, neuronal hyperexcitability, trigger factors (sleep changes, foods, stress, hormonal changes)
Treatments: Acute treatment (analgesics, triptans), avoid triggers, preventive therapy for frequent attacks, lifestyle measures (sleep, hydration)
Medications: Triptans (sumatriptan), NSAIDs (ibuprofen), Antiemetics (metoclopramide); preventive: beta-blockers, topiramate, amitriptyline

Overview: A contagious bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, primarily affecting the lungs but can be extrapulmonary; requires long multi-drug therapy.
Symptoms: Persistent cough (>2–3 weeks), Weight loss, Night sweats, Fever, Hemoptysis (sometimes)
Causes: Airborne transmission from an infectious person; risk increased by immunosuppression, malnutrition, crowded living conditions
Treatments: Confirmed diagnosis (microscopy, GeneXpert, culture), multi-drug antibiotic regimen with adherence support, contact tracing, supportive care
Medications: First-line: Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol (combination regimens per guidelines)

Overview: An infectious respiratory illness caused by SARS-CoV-2 with a wide spectrum from asymptomatic infection to severe pneumonia and multi-organ failure.
Symptoms: Fever, Cough, Shortness of breath, Fatigue, Loss of taste or smell, Myalgias, Sore throat
Causes: Infection with SARS-CoV-2 transmitted via respiratory droplets/aerosols and contaminated surfaces
Treatments: Supportive care for mild cases, oxygen and hospital-level care for severe disease, thrombosis prophylaxis in hospitalised patients, follow public health measures and vaccination
Medications: Symptomatic: Paracetamol; Antivirals (e.g., remdesivir) for select hospitalized patients; corticosteroids (dexamethasone) for severe/critical illness per guidelines

Overview: Infection of lung alveoli leading to cough, fever and breathing difficulty; caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi.
Symptoms: Cough (productive or dry), Fever, Shortness of breath, Chest pain (pleuritic), Fatigue
Causes: Bacterial pathogens (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae), viral (influenza, SARS-CoV-2), aspiration, impaired immunity
Treatments: Assess severity (outpatient vs inpatient), antibiotics for bacterial causes, antivirals if indicated, oxygen therapy, fluids and supportive care
Medications: Common antibiotics: Amoxicillin, Azithromycin, Doxycycline; selection guided by local guidelines and severity

Overview: A condition marked by low hemoglobin or red blood cell count, causing reduced oxygen delivery to tissues.
Symptoms: Fatigue, Weakness, Pallor, Shortness of breath, Dizziness, Palpitations
Causes: Iron deficiency (most common), chronic blood loss, hemolysis, vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, chronic disease
Treatments: Treat underlying cause, iron/B12/folate supplementation where indicated, transfusion for severe symptomatic anemia, manage chronic disease
Medications: Ferrous sulfate (iron), Folic acid, Vitamin B12 (cyanocobalamin); erythropoiesis-stimulating agents in selected chronic cases

Overview: A mosquito-borne viral illness that ranges from mild febrile disease to severe dengue with plasma leakage and hemorrhage.
Symptoms: High fever, Severe headache (often retro-orbital), Severe muscle/joint pain, Rash, Bleeding (in severe forms), Abdominal pain
Causes: Infection with dengue virus (four serotypes) transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes
Treatments: Supportive management with careful fluid balance, monitoring for warning signs of severe dengue, hospitalize severe cases, avoid NSAIDs
Medications: Paracetamol for fever and pain; IV fluids for dehydration; avoid aspirin/NSAIDs if bleeding risk

Overview: An acute neurological deficit due to ischemia (clot) or hemorrhage in the brain; time-sensitive emergency.
Symptoms: Sudden weakness or numbness (face/arm/leg), Difficulty speaking/understanding, Vision disturbance, Sudden severe headache, Loss of balance
Causes: Ischemic causes: thromboembolism (atherosclerosis, atrial fibrillation); Hemorrhagic: hypertension, aneurysm rupture; risk factors: hypertension, diabetes, smoking
Treatments: Immediate emergency assessment, CT/MRI to determine type, thrombolysis or thrombectomy for eligible ischemic strokes, blood pressure management, rehabilitation
Medications: Ischemic stroke: antiplatelets (aspirin) after evaluation; anticoagulation for cardioembolic stroke prevention (warfarin/DOACs) when indicated

Overview: A progressive obstructive lung disease (emphysema and chronic bronchitis) usually caused by long-term exposure to noxious particles, especially tobacco smoke.
Symptoms: Chronic cough, Sputum production, Dyspnea on exertion, Wheeze, Recurrent respiratory infections
Causes: Long-term smoking (primary cause), occupational dusts, air pollution, genetic factors (alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency)
Treatments: Smoking cessation, bronchodilator therapy, pulmonary rehabilitation, vaccinations, oxygen therapy for advanced disease
Medications: Bronchodilators: Short- and long-acting beta-agonists (salbutamol, salmeterol), Antimuscarinics (ipratropium, tiotropium), Inhaled corticosteroids for some

Overview: A progressive neurodegenerative disorder and the most common cause of dementia, characterized by memory loss and cognitive decline.
Symptoms: Progressive memory impairment, Difficulty with language and executive function, Disorientation, Behavioral changes
Causes: Age, genetic risk factors (e.g., APOE4), accumulation of amyloid-beta plaques and tau tangles (pathologic hallmarks)
Treatments: Cognitive and behavioral interventions, caregiver support, optimize comorbidities and safety, advance care planning
Medications: Cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine) for mild-to-moderate symptoms, Memantine for moderate-to-severe disease

Overview: A progressive movement disorder due to loss of dopaminergic neurons, causing tremor, stiffness and slowness.
Symptoms: Resting tremor, Bradykinesia (slowness), Muscle rigidity, Postural instability, Gait disturbance
Causes: Degeneration of substantia nigra dopaminergic neurons; genetic and environmental contributors
Treatments: Dopaminergic replacement therapy, physiotherapy, occupational therapy, surgical options (deep brain stimulation) in selected patients
Medications: Levodopa combined with carbidopa, Dopamine agonists (pramipexole), MAO-B inhibitors (selegiline)

Overview: A viral infection of the liver that can be acute or chronic; chronic infection increases risk of cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.
Symptoms: Fatigue, Jaundice, Dark urine, Abdominal pain, Loss of appetite (many are asymptomatic early)
Causes: Infection with hepatitis B virus transmitted via blood, sexual contact, perinatal transmission
Treatments: Acute: supportive care; Chronic: antiviral therapy to suppress replication, monitor liver function and screen for complications, vaccination for prevention
Medications: Antivirals for chronic infection: Tenofovir, Entecavir; vaccines for prevention

Overview: A blood-borne viral infection of the liver that often becomes chronic but is curable with modern antivirals.
Symptoms: Often asymptomatic initially; fatigue, jaundice, abdominal discomfort, elevated liver enzymes in some
Causes: Hepatitis C virus transmitted via blood (needles, transfusion, medical procedures)
Treatments: Diagnosis with HCV RNA testing; highly effective direct-acting antivirals (DAAs) to achieve cure; monitor liver for fibrosis/cirrhosis
Medications: Direct-acting antiviral regimens (sofosbuvir-based combinations) tailored per genotype and guidelines

Overview: A viral infection that progressively impairs the immune system if untreated; modern antiretroviral therapy (ART) controls the virus.
Symptoms: Acute: fever, sore throat, rash; chronic: weight loss, recurrent infections, night sweats if untreated
Causes: Human Immunodeficiency Virus transmitted via blood, sexual contact, perinatal transmission
Treatments: Lifelong antiretroviral therapy to suppress viral load, prophylaxis for opportunistic infections, monitoring and support services
Medications: Combination ART regimens (e.g., tenofovir + lamivudine/emtricitabine + integrase inhibitor such as dolutegravir) per guidelines

Overview: A seasonal respiratory infection caused by influenza viruses; can cause epidemics and severe illness in high-risk people.
Symptoms: Abrupt fever, Chills, Cough, Sore throat, Myalgia, Fatigue, Headache
Causes: Infection with influenza A or B via respiratory droplets; seasonal antigenic variation
Treatments: Supportive care, antivirals when indicated (high-risk or early treatment), annual vaccination for prevention
Medications: Oseltamivir for treatment in selected patients; supportive antipyretics and fluids

Overview: A primary varicella zoster virus infection causing vesicular rash; usually mild in children but can be severe in adults or immunocompromised.
Symptoms: Fever, Itchy vesicular rash in crops, Malaise
Causes: Varicella-zoster virus via respiratory droplets and direct contact; contagious
Treatments: Supportive care for uncomplicated cases (antipruritics, hydration), acyclovir for severe or high-risk patients, vaccination for prevention
Medications: Acyclovir in severe cases or high-risk patients; symptomatic treatment with antihistamines and topical agents

Overview: A highly contagious viral illness that causes fever and characteristic rash and can lead to serious complications.
Symptoms: High fever, Cough, Coryza (runny nose), Conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, Maculopapular rash
Causes: Measles virus via respiratory droplets; low vaccination coverage increases outbreaks
Treatments: Supportive care, vitamin A supplementation in children with severe disease, strict airborne precautions, vaccination (MMR) for prevention
Medications: Supportive only; vitamin A recommended in severe pediatric cases; prevention via MMR vaccine

Overview: Inflammation/infection of the middle ear, common in children and often following upper respiratory infection.
Symptoms: Ear pain (otalgia), Fever, Irritability in children, Hearing difficulty, Ear discharge if perforation
Causes: Eustachian tube dysfunction after cold/allergy, viral or bacterial infection (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae)
Treatments: Pain control and watchful waiting for mild cases, antibiotics for persistent or severe bacterial cases, tympanostomy tubes for recurrent disease
Medications: Analgesics (paracetamol/ibuprofen), Amoxicillin for bacterial otitis media when indicated

Overview: Inflammation of the stomach and intestines leading to diarrhea and vomiting; commonly viral but can be bacterial or parasitic.
Symptoms: Watery diarrhea, Vomiting, Abdominal cramps, Fever (sometimes), Dehydration risk
Causes: Viral pathogens (norovirus, rotavirus), bacterial (Salmonella, E. coli), contaminated food/water, person-to-person spread
Treatments: Oral rehydration therapy, maintain nutrition, antiemetics if severe, antibiotics only for certain bacterial causes or vulnerable patients
Medications: Oral rehydration salts for all; antibiotics (e.g., azithromycin) only when indicated by pathogen and severity

Overview: Mucosal ulceration of the stomach or duodenum causing epigastric pain; commonly due to H. pylori or NSAID use.
Symptoms: Burning epigastric pain, Worse with fasting or at night, Belching, Nausea, GI bleeding if severe
Causes: Helicobacter pylori infection, NSAID or aspirin use, smoking, stress-related factors
Treatments: Test and eradicate H. pylori if present, acid suppression with proton pump inhibitors, avoid NSAIDs, endoscopic management for bleeding
Medications: Proton pump inhibitors (omeprazole), H. pylori eradication regimens (PPI + clarithromycin + amoxicillin/metronidazole), H2 blockers as alternatives

Overview: Inflammation of the stomach lining causing pain and dyspeptic symptoms; can be acute or chronic.
Symptoms: Upper abdominal discomfort, Nausea, Bloating, Loss of appetite, Heartburn
Causes: H. pylori infection, NSAIDs, alcohol, stress, bile reflux, autoimmune causes
Treatments: Address underlying cause (stop NSAIDs, eradicate H. pylori), acid suppression, dietary modification
Medications: Proton pump inhibitors (omeprazole), Antacids, H. pylori eradication therapy when indicated

Overview: An allergic inflammation of nasal mucosa producing sneezing, congestion and rhinorrhea in response to airborne allergens.
Symptoms: Sneezing, Nasal itching, Runny nose (rhinorrhea), Nasal congestion, Watery eyes
Causes: IgE-mediated reaction to airborne allergens (pollen, dust mites, animal dander), seasonal or perennial
Treatments: Avoidance of triggers, intranasal corticosteroids for control, oral antihistamines for symptoms, saline nasal irrigation
Medications: Intranasal corticosteroids (fluticasone), Oral antihistamines (cetirizine), Nasal antihistamine sprays

Overview: An acute viral respiratory infection causing seasonal outbreaks and systemic symptoms; can be severe in high-risk groups.
Symptoms: Sudden fever, Chills, Cough, Sore throat, Muscle aches, Fatigue
Causes: Infection by influenza A or B viruses transmitted by respiratory droplets
Treatments: Rest, hydration, antivirals in high-risk/early treatment, annual vaccination
Medications: Oseltamivir (in selected patients), Supportive care

Overview: A mild upper respiratory viral infection caused by rhinoviruses and others; self-limited.
Symptoms: Runny or stuffy nose, Sneezing, Sore throat, Cough, Mild fever in some
Causes: Rhinoviruses, coronaviruses, adenoviruses transmitted via droplets and contact
Treatments: Supportive care: rest, fluids, symptomatic treatment (decongestants, analgesics), hand hygiene to prevent spread
Medications: Symptomatic: Paracetamol or ibuprofen for fever/pain, decongestants, saline nasal sprays

Overview: Inflammation of the bronchial airways causing cough; acute bronchitis is usually viral and self-limited.
Symptoms: Cough (may be productive), Wheeze, Chest discomfort, Mild fever
Causes: Usually viral infections (influenza, rhinovirus), smoking, air pollution; chronic bronchitis linked to smoking and COPD
Treatments: Acute: symptomatic treatment (fluids, cough relief), bronchodilators if wheeze; chronic: smoking cessation, bronchodilators, pulmonary rehab
Medications: Symptomatic therapy; bronchodilators (salbutamol) if wheezy; antibiotics only if bacterial superinfection suspected

Overview: Inflammation of paranasal sinuses causing facial pain, nasal obstruction and discharge; may be acute or chronic.
Symptoms: Facial pain/pressure, Nasal congestion, Thick purulent nasal discharge, Reduced sense of smell, Headache
Causes: Viral upper respiratory infection, bacterial infection, allergic rhinitis, anatomical blockage
Treatments: Most acute cases resolve with symptomatic care; antibiotics for persistent bacterial sinusitis, nasal corticosteroids, saline irrigation, address allergies
Medications: Intranasal corticosteroids, Oral antibiotics (amoxicillin-clavulanate) for bacterial cases, Analgesics

Overview: Inflammation/infection of the tonsils causing sore throat and fever; commonly viral but may be bacterial.
Symptoms: Severe sore throat, Difficulty swallowing, Fever, Tonsillar swelling/exudate, Tender cervical lymph nodes
Causes: Viral infections (most common) or bacterial (e.g., Group A Streptococcus), recurrent infections
Treatments: Supportive care for viral; antibiotics for confirmed bacterial infection; tonsillectomy for recurrent severe cases
Medications: Analgesics for pain; antibiotics (penicillin or amoxicillin) for streptococcal tonsillitis

Disease: Otitis Media (already included as Otitis Media)
Overview: See Otitis Media entry above.
Symptoms: See Otitis Media entry above.
Causes: See Otitis Media entry above.
Treatments: See Otitis Media entry above.
Medications: See Otitis Media entry above.

Overview: Joint pain, Stiffness, Swelling, Reduced motion
Symptoms: Aging, Autoimmune disorders, Joint injury
Causes: Physical therapy, Pain management, Exercise
Treatments: Ibuprofen, Naproxen, Methotrexate
Medications: Arthritis is inflammation of one or more joints, causing pain and stiffness that can worsen with age.

Overview: Cough with mucus, Fatigue, Shortness of breath, Chest discomfort
Symptoms: Viral infection, Smoking, Air pollution
Causes: Rest, Hydration, Avoid smoking
Treatments: Azithromycin (if bacterial), Cough suppressants
Medications: Bronchitis occurs when the bronchial tubes become inflamed and produce excess mucus.

Overview: Facial pain, Nasal congestion, Headache, Fever
Symptoms: Viral or bacterial infection, Allergies
Causes: Steam inhalation, Nasal sprays, Antibiotics if bacterial
Treatments: Amoxicillin, Decongestants
Medications: Sinusitis is inflammation or swelling of the tissue lining the sinuses, often following a cold or allergy.

Overview: Abdominal pain, Nausea, Vomiting, Jaundice
Symptoms: High cholesterol, Obesity, Rapid weight loss
Causes: Surgery (cholecystectomy), Dietary changes
Treatments: Ursodiol
Medications: Gallstones are hardened deposits of digestive fluid that form in the gallbladder.

Overview: Diarrhea, Vomiting, Abdominal cramps, Fever
Symptoms: Viral or bacterial infection, Contaminated food
Causes: Hydration, Rest, Light diet
Treatments: Oral rehydration salts, Antiemetics
Medications: Gastroenteritis is inflammation of the stomach and intestines, usually caused by an infection.

Overview: Abdominal pain, Bloating, Nausea, Indigestion
Symptoms: Helicobacter pylori infection, Alcohol, NSAIDs
Causes: Avoid irritants, Acid-reducing medication
Treatments: Omeprazole, Pantoprazole, Antacids
Medications: Gastritis is inflammation of the stomach lining often caused by infection or excessive alcohol use.

Overview: Stomach pain, Nausea, Bloating, Vomiting
Symptoms: Helicobacter pylori infection, Long-term NSAID use
Causes: Antibiotics, Acid suppression therapy
Treatments: Omeprazole, Clarithromycin, Amoxicillin
Medications: Peptic ulcers are open sores that develop on the inner lining of the stomach or duodenum.

Overview: Fatigue, Swelling, Nausea, Loss of appetite
Symptoms: Diabetes, Hypertension, Genetic factors
Causes: Dialysis, Blood pressure control, Diet management
Treatments: ACE inhibitors, Erythropoietin
Medications: CKD is a gradual loss of kidney function that filters waste and excess fluids from blood.

Overview: Burning urination, Frequent urination, Cloudy urine, Lower abdominal pain
Symptoms: Bacterial infection (E. coli)
Causes: Antibiotic therapy, Increased fluid intake
Treatments: Ciprofloxacin, Nitrofurantoin, Trimethoprim
Medications: UTIs are infections in any part of the urinary system, often caused by bacteria.

Overview: Fatigue, Jaundice, Abdominal pain, Nausea
Symptoms: Hepatitis A virus (HAV), Contaminated food/water
Causes: Rest, Hydration, Avoid alcohol
Treatments: No specific drug, Supportive care
Medications: Hepatitis A is a viral liver infection that spreads through contaminated food or water.

Overview: Fatigue, Jaundice, Dark urine, Joint pain
Symptoms: Hepatitis B virus (HBV)
Causes: Antiviral medication, Rest, Regular monitoring
Treatments: Tenofovir, Entecavir, Interferon
Medications: Hepatitis B affects the liver and can become chronic, leading to liver damage or cancer.

Overview: Fatigue, Jaundice, Muscle pain, Nausea
Symptoms: Hepatitis C virus (HCV), Blood-to-blood contact
Causes: Antiviral therapy
Treatments: Sofosbuvir, Ledipasvir, Ribavirin
Medications: Hepatitis C causes liver inflammation and is mainly spread through infected blood.

Overview: Severe abdominal pain (lower right), Fever, Nausea, Loss of appetite
Symptoms: Blockage in appendix, Infection
Causes: Surgical removal of appendix
Treatments: Pain relievers, Antibiotics before surgery
Medications: Appendicitis is inflammation of the appendix requiring prompt surgical treatment.

Overview: Fever, Cough, Sore throat, Muscle aches
Symptoms: Influenza virus
Causes: Rest, Hydration, Antiviral medication
Treatments: Oseltamivir (Tamiflu), Paracetamol
Medications: Influenza (flu) is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses.

Overview: Itchy rash, Fever, Fatigue, Loss of appetite
Symptoms: Varicella-zoster virus
Causes: Rest, Oatmeal baths, Antihistamines
Treatments: Acyclovir (severe cases), Calamine lotion
Medications: Chickenpox is a common viral infection that causes an itchy, blister-like rash.

Overview: Fever, Cough, Rash, Red eyes
Symptoms: Measles virus (paramyxovirus)
Causes: Supportive care, Vitamin A supplements
Treatments: Paracetamol, IV fluids
Medications: Measles is a highly contagious viral infection causing a red rash and flu-like symptoms.

Overview: Swollen salivary glands, Fever, Headache, Muscle pain
Symptoms: Mumps virus
Causes: Rest, Hydration, Pain relief
Treatments: Paracetamol, Ibuprofen
Medications: Mumps is a viral infection that affects the salivary glands near the ears, causing swelling and pain.

Overview: Rash, Fever, Swollen glands, Joint pain
Symptoms: Rubella virus
Causes: Supportive care
Treatments: Paracetamol, Ibuprofen
Medications: Rubella (German measles) is a mild viral infection that can cause serious birth defects if contracted during pregnancy.

Overview: Sore throat, Fever, Difficulty swallowing, Swollen tonsils
Symptoms: Viral or bacterial infection
Causes: Rest, Saltwater gargles, Antibiotics if bacterial
Treatments: Amoxicillin, Azithromycin
Medications: Tonsillitis is inflammation of the tonsils, often caused by infection.

Overview: Ear pain, Fever, Hearing loss, Fluid drainage
Symptoms: Bacterial or viral infection
Causes: Pain management, Antibiotics if severe
Treatments: Amoxicillin, Ibuprofen
Medications: Otitis media is an infection of the middle ear, common in children.

Overview: Red eyes, Itching, Discharge, Swollen eyelids
Symptoms: Viral or bacterial infection, Allergies
Causes: Warm compresses, Eye drops, Avoid touching eyes
Treatments: Ciprofloxacin eye drops, Antihistamine drops
Medications: Conjunctivitis, or pink eye, is inflammation of the membrane covering the white part of the eye.

Overview: Red scaly patches, Itching, Dry skin, Cracked skin
Symptoms: Autoimmune disorder, Genetics, Stress
Causes: Topical therapy, Phototherapy, Medication
Treatments: Corticosteroid creams, Methotrexate
Medications: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition that speeds up skin cell growth.

Overview: Itchy skin, Red patches, Cracks, Dryness
Symptoms: Allergies, Immune system dysfunction
Causes: Moisturizers, Avoid triggers, Steroid creams
Treatments: Hydrocortisone, Antihistamines
Medications: Eczema is an inflammatory skin condition causing dry, itchy, and red skin.

Overview: Intense itching, Rash, Blisters, Skin irritation
Symptoms: Mite infestation (Sarcoptes scabiei)
Causes: Topical creams, Washing clothes/bedding
Treatments: Permethrin, Ivermectin
Medications: Scabies is a contagious skin infestation caused by tiny mites that burrow into the skin.

Overview: Circular rash, Itching, Redness, Scaling
Symptoms: Fungal infection
Causes: Topical antifungal cream
Treatments: Clotrimazole, Terbinafine
Medications: Ringworm is a common fungal skin infection forming circular, ring-like rashes.

Overview: Painful rash, Blisters, Burning sensation
Symptoms: Reactivation of varicella-zoster virus
Causes: Antiviral therapy, Pain relief
Treatments: Acyclovir, Valacyclovir
Medications: Shingles (Herpes Zoster) occurs when the chickenpox virus reactivates later in life.

Overview: Sneezing, Runny nose, Itchy eyes, Nasal congestion
Symptoms: Allergens (dust, pollen, pets)
Causes: Avoid allergens, Antihistamines, Nasal sprays
Treatments: Cetirizine, Loratadine, Fluticasone
Medications: Allergic rhinitis is an allergic reaction causing inflammation of the nasal passages.

Overview: Weight gain, Fatigue, Shortness of breath, Joint pain
Symptoms: Overeating, Genetics, Lack of exercise
Causes: Diet control, Physical activity, Counseling
Treatments: Orlistat
Medications: Obesity is excess body fat accumulation increasing risk of heart disease and diabetes.

Overview: Weight loss, Rapid heartbeat, Anxiety, Tremors
Symptoms: Overactive thyroid gland, Graves’ disease
Causes: Medication, Radioactive iodine therapy
Treatments: Methimazole, Propylthiouracil
Medications: Hyperthyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland produces too much thyroid hormone.

Overview: Fatigue, Weight gain, Cold intolerance, Dry skin
Symptoms: Underactive thyroid gland, Iodine deficiency
Causes: Hormone replacement therapy
Treatments: Levothyroxine
Medications: Hypothyroidism occurs when the thyroid does not produce enough hormones, slowing metabolism.

Overview: Irregular periods, Weight gain, Acne, Excess hair growth
Symptoms: Hormonal imbalance, Genetics
Causes: Lifestyle changes, Hormonal therapy
Treatments: Metformin, Oral contraceptives
Medications: PCOS is a hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts, affecting fertility.

Overview: Excessive worry, Restlessness, Fatigue, Insomnia
Symptoms: Stress, Genetics, Brain chemistry
Causes: Therapy, Relaxation techniques, Medication
Treatments: SSRIs, Benzodiazepines
Medications: Anxiety disorder causes persistent fear or worry that interferes with daily life.

Overview: Sadness, Fatigue, Loss of interest, Insomnia
Symptoms: Chemical imbalance, Trauma, Genetics
Causes: Therapy, Exercise, Medication
Treatments: SSRIs, Sertraline, Fluoxetine
Medications: Depression is a mood disorder that causes persistent sadness and loss of interest in activities.

Overview: A condition where the thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormones, slowing metabolism and body functions.
Symptoms: Fatigue, Weight gain, Cold intolerance, Constipation, Dry skin, Hair loss, Slowed heart rate
Causes: Autoimmune thyroiditis (Hashimoto's), thyroid surgery or radiation, certain medications, iodine deficiency
Treatments: Thyroid hormone replacement, monitor TSH and adjust dose, treat associated symptoms and risk factors
Medications: Levothyroxine (synthetic T4) administered orally with dose titration by TSH levels

Overview: Excess production of thyroid hormones leading to increased metabolic rate and sympathetic symptoms.
Symptoms: Weight loss, Heat intolerance, Palpitations, Tremor, Nervousness, Increased sweating, Diarrhea
Causes: Graves' disease (autoimmune), toxic multinodular goiter, excessive thyroid hormone intake
Treatments: Antithyroid medications, radioactive iodine ablation, beta-blockers for symptomatic control, surgery in select cases
Medications: Methimazole or Propylthiouracil (antithyroid drugs); Beta-blockers (propranolol) to control symptoms

Overview: A hormonal disorder in people with ovaries, characterized by irregular periods, hyperandrogenism and polycystic ovaries; associated with metabolic risks.
Symptoms: Irregular menstrual cycles, Acne, Excess hair growth (hirsutism), Weight gain, Infertility
Causes: Insulin resistance, genetic predisposition, hormonal imbalance (excess androgens)
Treatments: Lifestyle modification (weight loss, exercise), hormonal regulation (combined oral contraceptives), ovulation induction for fertility, manage metabolic issues
Medications: Metformin for insulin resistance, Combined oral contraceptives for cycle control, Clomiphene or letrozole for ovulation induction

Overview: A group of conditions causing abnormal menstrual bleeding, painful periods or irregular cycles.
Symptoms: Heavy menstrual bleeding, Irregular cycles, Painful cramps (dysmenorrhea), Spotting between periods
Causes: Hormonal imbalances, uterine fibroids, polyps, coagulation disorders, pregnancy-related causes, ovulatory dysfunction
Treatments: Treat underlying cause, hormonal therapy (combined oral contraceptives, progestins), NSAIDs for pain, surgical options for structural causes
Medications: NSAIDs for pain (ibuprofen), Tranexamic acid for heavy bleeding in select cases, hormonal therapies for regulation

Overview: Physiological transition marking end of menstruation, often accompanied by vasomotor and genitourinary symptoms.
Symptoms: Hot flashes, Night sweats, Vaginal dryness, Mood changes, Sleep disturbances
Causes: Decline in ovarian estrogen production with age and hormonal changes
Treatments: Lifestyle measures, non-hormonal therapies for symptoms, hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for selected patients after risk-benefit discussion
Medications: Vasomotor symptom options: Low-dose HRT for appropriate candidates; non-hormonal: SSRIs/SNRIs, clonidine; vaginal estrogen for local urogenital symptoms

Overview: The inability to achieve or maintain an erection sufficient for satisfactory sexual performance.
Symptoms: Difficulty achieving erection, Reduced rigidity, Decreased sexual confidence, Relationship stress
Causes: Vascular disease, diabetes, neurological disorders, medications, psychological factors, low testosterone
Treatments: Address underlying causes (cardiometabolic health), lifestyle changes, PDE5 inhibitors, vacuum devices, counseling for psychogenic ED
Medications: PDE5 inhibitors: Sildenafil, Tadalafil, Vardenafil (use with caution and contraindications screening)

Overview: Noncancerous enlargement of the prostate gland causing lower urinary tract symptoms in older men.
Symptoms: Nocturia, Increased urinary frequency, Hesitancy, Weak stream, Incomplete bladder emptying
Causes: Age-related prostate growth and hormonal influences (androgens)
Treatments: Watchful waiting for mild cases, medical therapy to relax prostate/muscle tone, surgical options if obstructive or refractory
Medications: Alpha-blockers (tamsulosin) to improve flow, 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors (finasteride) to reduce prostate size; surgical options like TURP

Overview: A common skin condition involving blocked hair follicles and inflammation, often on the face, chest and back.
Symptoms: Comedones (blackheads/whiteheads), Papules, Pustules, Nodules, Scarring in severe disease
Causes: Follicular hyperkeratinization, excess sebum production, Cutibacterium acnes proliferation, hormonal influences
Treatments: Topical therapies for mild disease, oral antibiotics for moderate inflammatory acne, retinoids, hormonal treatments for female patients
Medications: Topical benzoyl peroxide, Topical retinoids (tretinoin), Oral doxycycline for inflammatory acne, Oral isotretinoin for severe nodulocystic cases under specialist supervision

Overview: A chronic inflammatory skin condition causing itchy, red, and scaly skin, often starting in childhood.
Symptoms: Intense itching, Red or brownish-gray patches, Dry skin, Oozing or crusting in flares
Causes: Genetic predisposition, skin barrier dysfunction, immune dysregulation, environmental triggers (allergens, irritants)
Treatments: Skin hydration and emollients, topical corticosteroids for flares, topical calcineurin inhibitors, identify and avoid triggers
Medications: Topical emollients, Topical corticosteroids for flares, Topical calcineurin inhibitors (tacrolimus) for sensitive areas; systemic immunomodulators in severe cases

Overview: Superficial fungal infections of the skin causing characteristic ring-shaped lesions.
Symptoms: Itchy circular red patch with central clearing, scaling, spread outward from center
Causes: Dermatophyte fungi (Trichophyton, Microsporum, Epidermophyton) transmitted by contact, moist environments
Treatments: Topical antifungals for localized disease, oral antifungals for extensive or hair/nail involvement, hygiene measures
Medications: Topical azoles (clotrimazole, miconazole) for skin; Oral terbinafine or itraconazole for nail/scalp infections

Overview: A fungal infection of the feet commonly between toes and on soles, causing itching and scaling.
Symptoms: Itching, Burning, Peeling or cracking skin between toes, Foul odor in some cases
Causes: Dermatophyte infection often acquired from communal wet areas, occlusive footwear increases risk
Treatments: Topical antifungal creams and powders, keeping feet dry and ventilated, change socks and footwear regularly
Medications: Topical terbinafine, topical azoles (miconazole), oral antifungals for severe or recalcitrant cases

Overview: A viral infection causing painful swelling of the salivary glands, mainly parotid glands.
Symptoms: Fever, Swollen/tender parotid glands, Painful chewing, Headache, Malaise
Causes: Mumps virus transmitted via respiratory droplets; decreased incidence in vaccinated populations
Treatments: Supportive care (rest, hydration, analgesics), isolation to prevent spread, vaccination prevents disease
Medications: Supportive treatment only; MMR vaccine for prevention

Overview: A generally mild viral illness in children/adults but concerning in pregnancy due to congenital rubella syndrome.
Symptoms: Low-grade fever, Rash starting on face and spreading, Lymphadenopathy, Mild arthralgia
Causes: Rubella virus transmitted by respiratory droplets; risk of fetal infection if in early pregnancy
Treatments: Supportive care; prevention via vaccination, pregnancy management includes screening and counseling
Medications: No specific antivirals; MMR vaccination is key prevention

Overview: A systemic bacterial infection characterized by prolonged fever and abdominal symptoms; common in areas with poor sanitation.
Symptoms: Sustained high fever, Abdominal pain, Constipation or diarrhea, Headache, Relative bradycardia
Causes: Ingestion of Salmonella typhi via contaminated food/water, poor sanitation
Treatments: Prompt diagnosis with blood/stool culture where possible, appropriate antibiotic therapy, supportive care and hydration
Medications: Antibiotics guided by local resistance patterns (e.g., ceftriaxone, azithromycin) per guidelines

Overview: An acute diarrheal illness that can cause severe dehydration and death if untreated; caused by Vibrio cholerae.
Symptoms: Watery diarrhea (rice-water stools), Vomiting, Rapid dehydration, Hypotension, Electrolyte imbalance
Causes: Ingestion of contaminated water or food with Vibrio cholerae, poor sanitation and overcrowding
Treatments: Rapid rehydration with oral rehydration salts (ORS) or IV fluids for severe dehydration, antibiotics in severe cases, public health measures for prevention
Medications: ORS for all; antibiotics (single-dose azithromycin or doxycycline) in severe cases per local guidance

Overview: A bacterial zoonotic infection acquired from contact with animal urine contaminated water/soil; can cause systemic illness.
Symptoms: High fever, Myalgia (notably calf muscles), Headache, Jaundice in severe cases, Conjunctival suffusion
Causes: Exposure to contaminated water/soil or animal urine (rodents, livestock), occupational and recreational risks
Treatments: Early diagnosis and antibiotic therapy, supportive care for complications (renal failure, pulmonary hemorrhage)
Medications: Doxycycline for mild cases, IV penicillin or ceftriaxone for severe disease per clinical judgement

Overview: A parasitic infection transmitted by mosquitoes causing lymphatic dysfunction and chronic swelling (elephantiasis) in endemic areas.
Symptoms: Fever in acute phase, Lymphangitis, Chronic lymphedema with swelling of limbs/genitalia, recurrent infections
Causes: Nematode parasites (Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia spp.) transmitted by mosquitoes
Treatments: Mass drug administration in endemic areas for control, antiparasitic therapy (DEC, ivermectin) and management of lymphedema with hygiene and physiotherapy
Medications: Antiparasitics like Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) or ivermectin in combination with albendazole in mass treatment programs; management of lymphedema conservatively

Overview: A contagious skin infestation by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei causing intense itching, especially at night.
Symptoms: Intense pruritus, Burrows or papular rash in interdigital spaces, wrist, waistline, genitalia
Causes: Close personal contact or shared bedding/clothing with an infected person spreads mites
Treatments: Topical scabicidal agents applied to entire body, treat close contacts and decontaminate clothing/bed linen, symptomatic itch control
Medications: Topical permethrin 5% cream is first-line; oral ivermectin for outbreaks or crusted scabies in specialist settings

Overview: Infestation of scalp hair by lice causing itching and visible nits; common in school-aged children.
Symptoms: Itching of scalp, Visible nits (eggs) on hair shafts, Scratch marks or secondary infection from scratching
Causes: Direct head-to-head contact or sharing of contaminated items (hats, combs)
Treatments: Topical pediculicides applied per instructions, repeat treatment to kill newly hatched nits, combing to remove nits, treat household contacts if necessary
Medications: Permethrin 1% lotion or pyrethrin-based shampoos; oral ivermectin in resistant or outbreak situations

Overview: Acute gastrointestinal illness caused by ingestion of contaminated food or toxins leading to rapid onset symptoms.
Symptoms: Nausea, Vomiting, Abdominal cramps, Diarrhea, Fever (sometimes), Dehydration risk
Causes: Contaminated food with bacteria (Salmonella, E. coli), toxins (Staphylococcus aureus), or viruses; improper storage or cooking
Treatments: Supportive care with rehydration, electrolyte replacement, antibiotics only when indicated by pathogen and severity
Medications: Oral rehydration solutions; antibiotics (e.g., azithromycin) only for specific bacterial pathogens when indicated

Overview: Solid deposits (stones) forming in the gallbladder that can cause biliary colic or complications like cholecystitis.
Symptoms: Biliary colic: episodic right upper quadrant pain often after fatty meals, nausea, vomiting; jaundice if obstructive
Causes: Cholesterol supersaturation of bile, gallbladder stasis, risk factors: female sex, obesity, rapid weight loss, age
Treatments: Asymptomatic stones often observed; symptomatic stones: surgical removal of gallbladder (cholecystectomy), manage complications like cholecystitis, ERCP for common bile duct stones
Medications: Analgesics for pain; elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic disease; ursodeoxycholic acid in select non-surgical candidates to dissolve cholesterol stones (limited use)

Overview: Inflammation of the pancreas presenting acutely with severe abdominal pain; can be mild or life-threatening.
Symptoms: Severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, Nausea, Vomiting, Fever, Elevated pancreatic enzymes (amylase/lipase)
Causes: Gallstones (common cause), alcohol excess, hypertriglyceridemia, medications, ERCP-related injury
Treatments: Hospitalize for fluid resuscitation, pain control, nil per os initially, treat underlying cause (remove gallstones), nutritional support
Medications: Analgesics (opioids for severe pain), treat cause (e.g., cholecystectomy for gallstone pancreatitis), manage complications in ICU

Overview: Malignant tumor of the lung often linked to tobacco exposure; presents late with respiratory and systemic symptoms.
Symptoms: Persistent cough, Hemoptysis, Chest pain, Breathlessness, Weight loss, Recurrent infections
Causes: Tobacco smoking (primary risk factor), occupational exposures (asbestos), air pollution, genetic factors
Treatments: Staging with imaging and biopsy; treatment options depend on stage: surgery, radiotherapy, chemotherapy, targeted therapy and immunotherapy for selected molecular subtypes
Medications: Surgical resection for early stage, platinum-based chemotherapy, targeted agents (EGFR, ALK inhibitors) for mutation-positive cancers, immune checkpoint inhibitors where indicated

Overview: Inflammation of the pharynx commonly causing sore throat; viral causes are most common but bacterial (strep throat) needs specific treatment.
Symptoms: Sore throat, Painful swallowing, Fever (in bacterial cases), Tonsillar exudates in some, tender cervical lymphadenopathy
Causes: Viral infections (most common: rhinovirus, adenovirus), Group A Streptococcus (bacterial), irritants
Treatments: Supportive care for viral pharyngitis (hydration, analgesics); antibiotics for confirmed streptococcal pharyngitis to prevent complications
Medications: Analgesics (paracetamol, ibuprofen); antibiotics (penicillin/amoxicillin) for confirmed Group A Streptococcus

Overview: "Small painful ulcers of the oral mucosa typically self-limited but recurrent in some individuals."
Symptoms: Painful round/oval ulcers with a yellowish base and red halo, difficulty eating/speaking
Causes: Minor trauma, stress, nutritional deficiencies (B12, folate), aphthous predisposition, systemic diseases (e.g., IBD)
Treatments: Topical protective agents, topical corticosteroids for severe recurrent ulcers, address nutritional deficiencies, maintain oral hygiene
Medications: Topical corticosteroid gels (triamcinolone), topical analgesics, treat deficiencies (vitamin B12/folate) if present

Overview: Demineralization of tooth enamel and dentin due to bacterial acid production leading to cavities and toothache if untreated.
Symptoms: Tooth sensitivity, Pain with chewing, Visible cavitation or dark spots, Bad breath
Causes: Plaque bacteria metabolizing sugars to acids, poor oral hygiene, frequent sugar intake, lack of fluoride
Treatments: Dental restoration (fillings), root canal treatment for deep decay, extraction for non-restorable teeth, preventive oral hygiene and fluoride
Medications: Local dental treatment: fillings (amalgam/composite), fluoride varnish for prevention; antibiotics only if secondary infection present

Overview: Inflammation of the gums due to plaque accumulation; reversible in early stages with good oral hygiene.
Symptoms: Red, swollen, and bleeding gums especially on brushing, bad breath
Causes: Dental plaque biofilm buildup, poor oral hygiene, smoking, certain medications, systemic conditions like diabetes
Treatments: Improved oral hygiene with brushing and flossing, professional dental cleaning (scaling), treat contributing factors
Medications: Professional dental cleaning; topical antiseptics (chlorhexidine) for short-term adjunct; antibiotics only if acute spreading infection

Overview: A neurological disorder characterized by recurrent unprovoked seizures due to abnormal brain electrical activity.
Symptoms: Seizure episodes (focal or generalized), transient loss of awareness, convulsions, confusion post-ictal
Causes: Genetic predisposition, structural brain lesions, infections, head trauma, metabolic causes
Treatments: Diagnosis with EEG and neuroimaging, antiseizure medication tailored to seizure type, surgery for refractory focal epilepsy, lifestyle adjustments and safety counseling
Medications: Antiseizure drugs: Valproate, Carbamazepine, Levetiracetam, Lamotrigine depending on seizure type

Overview: A group of mental health disorders characterized by excessive worry, fear, or nervousness interfering with daily function.
Symptoms: Excessive worry, Restlessness, Palpitations, Shortness of breath, Sleep disturbance, Muscle tension
Causes: Genetic vulnerability, stress, neurochemical imbalances, life events, medical conditions
Treatments: Psychological therapies (CBT), lifestyle measures, relaxation techniques, pharmacotherapy for moderate–severe cases
Medications: SSRIs (sertraline, escitalopram), SNRIs, short-term benzodiazepines for acute severe anxiety under supervision

Overview: A mood disorder with persistent low mood, loss of interest, and functional impairment; can be recurrent or chronic.
Symptoms: Persistent sadness, Loss of interest, Changes in appetite or sleep, Fatigue, Suicidal thoughts in severe cases
Causes: Genetic predisposition, psychosocial stressors, neurotransmitter changes, chronic medical illness
Treatments: Psychotherapy (CBT, interpersonal therapy), antidepressant medication for moderate–severe cases, lifestyle interventions and social support
Medications: Antidepressants: SSRIs (sertraline, fluoxetine), SNRIs, psychotherapy; monitor for response and suicidality

Overview: A common sleep disorder where individuals have difficulty falling asleep, staying asleep, or waking up too early and not being able to go back to sleep.
Symptoms: Difficulty falling asleep, Frequent awakenings, Daytime fatigue, Irritability, Poor concentration
Causes: Stress, Anxiety, Depression, Poor sleep habits, Caffeine or alcohol, Certain medications
Treatments: Sleep hygiene improvement, Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), Relaxation training, Treat underlying cause
Medications: Melatonin, Zolpidem, Eszopiclone, Trazodone (under supervision)

Overview: A chronic brain disorder that affects a person's ability to think clearly, manage emotions, make decisions, and relate to others.
Symptoms: Hallucinations, Delusions, Disorganized thinking, Social withdrawal, Reduced emotional expression
Causes: Genetic predisposition, Dopamine imbalance, Brain structure abnormalities, Environmental stressors
Treatments: Psychosocial therapy, Cognitive behavioral therapy, Family support, Vocational rehabilitation, Long-term medication adherence
Medications: Antipsychotics (Risperidone, Olanzapine, Clozapine, Aripiprazole)

Overview: A mood disorder characterized by episodes of mania (elevated mood, energy) alternating with depression (low mood, hopelessness).
Symptoms: Mood swings, Increased energy (mania), Decreased need for sleep, Depression, Irritability, Impulsivity
Causes: Genetic factors, Neurochemical imbalances, Stressful life events, Sleep deprivation
Treatments: Mood stabilization therapy, Psychotherapy, Lifestyle regulation (sleep, routine), Avoid substance use
Medications: Lithium, Valproate, Lamotrigine, Atypical antipsychotics (Quetiapine, Olanzapine)

Overview: A mental health condition triggered by experiencing or witnessing a traumatic event.
Symptoms: Flashbacks, Nightmares, Severe anxiety, Avoidance of reminders, Hypervigilance, Sleep disturbances
Causes: Exposure to traumatic events (e.g., accidents, assault, war), Genetic susceptibility, Lack of social support
Treatments: Trauma-focused therapy (CBT, EMDR), Support groups, Relaxation techniques, Medication when needed
Medications: SSRIs (Sertraline, Paroxetine), Prazosin (for nightmares), Antianxiety medications (as needed)

Overview: A mental disorder involving recurrent, intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviors (compulsions) performed to reduce anxiety.
Symptoms: Repetitive hand washing, Checking, Counting, Intrusive thoughts, Anxiety when rituals not performed
Causes: Genetic factors, Serotonin dysregulation, Stressful life events, Brain circuitry abnormalities
Treatments: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (exposure and response prevention), Psychotherapy, Supportive care
Medications: SSRIs (Fluoxetine, Sertraline), Clomipramine

Overview: A type of anxiety disorder with recurrent unexpected panic attacks and fear of future attacks.
Symptoms: Sudden intense fear, Palpitations, Shortness of breath, Chest pain, Dizziness, Trembling
Causes: Genetic predisposition, Stress, Imbalance of neurotransmitters (serotonin, norepinephrine), Caffeine or stimulant use
Treatments: Cognitive behavioral therapy, Breathing and relaxation techniques, Gradual exposure therapy
Medications: SSRIs (Paroxetine, Sertraline), Benzodiazepines (short-term use), Beta-blockers (for physical symptoms)

Overview: A developmental disorder affecting communication, social interaction, and behavior; varies in severity.
Symptoms: Difficulty with communication, Repetitive behaviors, Social withdrawal, Sensory sensitivities
Causes: Genetic factors, Brain development differences, Environmental influences during pregnancy
Treatments: Behavioral therapy, Speech and occupational therapy, Social skills training, Educational support
Medications: No specific cure; medications for associated symptoms (e.g., Risperidone for irritability)

Overview: A neurodevelopmental disorder marked by persistent inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity affecting functioning.
Symptoms: Inattention, Impulsivity, Hyperactivity, Poor organization, Forgetfulness
Causes: Genetic factors, Dopamine imbalance, Brain structural differences, Environmental risks
Treatments: Behavioral therapy, Classroom modifications, Parent training, Structured routines
Medications: Stimulants (Methylphenidate, Amphetamine), Non-stimulants (Atomoxetine, Guanfacine)

Overview: A clouding of the normally clear lens of the eye, leading to blurred vision and glare sensitivity.
Symptoms: Blurred vision, Glare, Faded colors, Poor night vision, Frequent prescription changes
Causes: Aging (most common), Diabetes, Prolonged steroid use, Eye injury, UV exposure
Treatments: Surgical removal of the cloudy lens and replacement with an artificial lens
Medications: No medication reverses cataract; only surgery is definitive treatment

Overview: A group of eye conditions that damage the optic nerve, often due to high intraocular pressure, leading to vision loss.
Symptoms: Loss of peripheral vision, Eye pain (in acute cases), Blurred vision, Halos around lights
Causes: Increased intraocular pressure, Family history, Age, Diabetes, Eye injury
Treatments: Lower intraocular pressure through eye drops, Laser or surgical therapy if needed
Medications: Prostaglandin analogs (Latanoprost), Beta blockers (Timolol), Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

Overview: Inflammation of the conjunctiva causing redness and discharge; can be viral, bacterial, or allergic.
Symptoms: Red eyes, Itching, Tearing, Discharge, Burning sensation, Swollen eyelids
Causes: Viral/bacterial infection, Allergens, Irritants (smoke, dust), Contact lens overuse
Treatments: Hygiene (avoid touching eyes), Cold compresses, Treat cause (antibiotic if bacterial)
Medications: Antibiotic drops (Ciprofloxacin, Erythromycin) if bacterial; Antihistamine drops if allergic

Overview: A condition where the eyes do not produce enough tears or tears evaporate too quickly, causing discomfort.
Symptoms: Eye dryness, Burning, Gritty sensation, Redness, Blurred vision
Causes: Aging, Prolonged screen use, Hormonal changes, Contact lenses, Medications
Treatments: Artificial tears, Avoid screen strain, Humidifier use, Punctal plugs for severe cases
Medications: Artificial tear drops, Cyclosporine ophthalmic (Restasis)

Overview: Pain and pressure around the sinuses, often due to sinus infection or inflammation.
Symptoms: Facial pain, Pressure around eyes/forehead, Nasal congestion, Fatigue, Worsens on bending forward
Causes: Sinus infection, Allergies, Nasal polyps, Cold, Deviated septum
Treatments: Treat underlying sinusitis/allergy, Steam inhalation, Nasal irrigation, Pain relief
Medications: Decongestants (Pseudoephedrine), Antihistamines, Nasal corticosteroids, Analgesics (Ibuprofen)

Overview: A protrusion of an organ or tissue through a weak spot in the surrounding muscle or tissue wall.
Symptoms: Visible lump, Pain or discomfort when lifting, Swelling, Pressure sensation, Possible intestinal obstruction
Causes: Increased abdominal pressure (heavy lifting, chronic cough), Weak muscles, Obesity, Pregnancy
Treatments: Surgical repair (herniorrhaphy or mesh repair), Lifestyle modification to reduce strain
Medications: Pain relief (NSAIDs) for symptom control pre-surgery

Overview: Swollen, twisted veins usually in the legs caused by valve weakness and poor circulation.
Symptoms: Visible bulging veins, Leg pain or heaviness, Swelling, Skin discoloration, Itching
Causes: Weak vein valves, Genetic predisposition, Prolonged standing, Obesity, Pregnancy
Treatments: Compression stockings, Elevate legs, Exercise, Sclerotherapy or laser ablation in severe cases
Medications: No specific medication; pain relief with NSAIDs, topical agents for inflammation
